Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Consortium for the 2016 Learning Analytics and Knowledge Conference

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
Using data analytics has revolutionized many academic disciplines, such as Astrophysics and Biology. In addition, it has changed the commercial world and critical services like healthcare. The field of education research is also beginning this change. The Society for Learning Analytics Research (SoLAR) is a key player in effecting this change. This project will support a Doctoral Consortium at the SoLAR 2016 conference - the 6th Annual International Learning Analytics and Knowledge (LAK) Conference, to be held in Edinborough, UK in 2016. Participating in the consortium will prepare current doctoral students from the diverse research backgrounds that make up the interdisciplinary field of Learning Analytics (LA), including computer science, information science, psychology, communication, education, artificial intelligence, and cognitive science. It will also allow them to network with each other and with professors and practitioners who are currently engaged in learning analytics research and related work to ensure the continued development of this community. These activities are critical and timely. The upcoming generation of LA researchers will play a vital role in realizing the potential of using data to improve outcomes for elementary, secondary, and post-secondary students in learning, motivation, and perseverance.

Learning Analytics is an interdisciplinary field whose goal is to advance and apply knowledge about learning sciences and education to improve all aspects of learning. LA methods include data visualization, data mining, data science, and mixed methods approaches combining qualitative and quantitative methods (e.g., interviews and back-end, clickstream data analysis). Capacity building is a central concern within the LA community. SoLAR has historically addressed these needs, in part, through specialized workshops held in conjunction with the Society's major conference. The Doctoral Consortium workshops host PhD students who are grappling with their dissertation research. This grant provides travel support to US scholars selected through a competitive application process to participate in this event. They present their work for feedback both in the context of workshop, where they receive advice from a panel of expert mentors, and in a poster session in which they interact with the full conference audience. In addition, their work is published in the proceedings of the conference.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This NSF award has supported the Doctoral Consortium at the International Learning Analytics and Knowledge (LAK) for two consecutive years. Specifically, it supported the participation of 5 U.S. doctoral students and 5 faculty mentors at the LAK 16 Doctoral Consortium at the University of Edinburgh in Edinburgh UK, and the participation of 3 U.S. doctoral students and 4 faculty mentors at the LAK 17 Doctoral Consortium at Simon Fraser University in Vancouver Canada. Each year, a total of ten doctoral students from North America and elsewhere were selected through a competitive application process to participate in the Doctoral Consortium. Selection criteria included whether their work was conceptually motivated, had implications for learning theory, and used analytics to provide direction for understanding and supporting learning processes and outcomes. These two Doctoral Consortium cohorts were represented by students from Canada, Europe, Australia, South Africa, and the U.S. Non-U.S. students were funded by the Society for Learning Analytics Research (SoLAR).The student participants came from a diverse set of disciplinary programs, including psychology, computer science, information sciences, and education. Eleven students of them were female and nine were male. Overall, this project helped to create a space for the field of learning analytics to bring together a diverse group of doctoral students for capacity building activities.

During the Doctoral Consortium at each LAK conference, selected doctoral students and faculty mentors participated in one full day preceding. All students were asked to present their work to the whole group, followed by questions and comments from the full group and break-out group discussions facilitated by faculty mentors. This interactive format allowed both broad exposure to each other’s work and more specific feedback to individual students. The day culminated in a faculty panel which addressed questions about the faculty positions, funding, the job search, and publication strategies, with an eye towards these issues with respect to Learning Analytics and international differences in Higher Education. Throughout the day, additional senior researchers who were attending LAK also stopped by the DC to participate as their time allowed. All DC participants, students and faculty, attended a dinner together at a local restaurant. In addition, all DC students presented their work during the LAK conference poster session.

To assess the impact of participating in the Doctoral Consortium, the PI and Co-PI administered a survey to the students each year. The response rates were above 70% in both years. Overall, the student response to the LAK 16 & 17 Doctoral Consortia was very positive. Students found the Doctoral Consortium useful for enriching their understanding about various aspects of learning analytics research, developing professional contacts in the community, fostering a spirit of collaborative research across institutions, and facilitating career advancements. Faculty mentors were also very satisfied with the level of engagement and supportive dialogue. Because of its success and recognized importance for the field, the Doctoral Consortium has become a tradition for the LAK conference. Apparently the combined funding from NSF and SoLAR has collectively contributed to these outcomes.
